Nereis, part two: Place some very recently fertilized eggs in
a drop of thick chinese ink suspension in the center of the bottom of
a Syracuse dish. As
the jelly is secreted, the attached sperm causes
a canal to form in the secreted jelly into which particles of ink will
penetrate. ihe ink thus marks the entrance point of the sperm. After
the canal has filled with ink, add sea water and, if time pemnits, ob-

The Chaetopterus egg is rather dark and granular. It is 
more than l00 microns in diameter, but before fertilization the eggs
are often not quite spherical. The polar bodies are larger than in
Nereis, and the egg divides to form two unequal cells by means of a
polar lobe at the vegetal pole.
when the e'g is
taken from the female it contains a large im~
mature nucleus %germinal vesicle), as does the Nereis egg, but unlike
the Nereis egg, it partly matures when placed in sea water even if it
is not fertilized. A number of species of eggs partly mature when
they come into sea water and Pgsteels (Bib. ref. l2) has shown that 5
this
is dependent upon the presence of Calcium in the sea water.
Chaetopteggs eggs develop quite rapidly. If eggs are fertilized

after the partial maturation in sea water has been completed,
develop as rapidly as eggs inseminated l2-l5 minutes earlier
first placed in sea water (Bib. ref. 14). When eggs are fertile
after having been in sea water for l5 minutes or longer, the
following schedule applies to aof of the eggs in a population reared
at 210 C. (Bib. ref.
l4) (time counted from fertilization): polar
body, l4.5 minutes; 2nd polar body, 27 minutes; "pear shaped" stage,
46 minutes; polar lobe bulge, 52 minutes; cleavage with polar lobe
attached, 58 minutes; completed cleavage with polar lobe resorbed into
one blastomere, 62 minutes; 4 cell stage, 82 minutes. lf the labora-
tory air temperature
is about 24O C., the development will be more
rapid, and about at the rate indicated in the descriptive text below.
